verses.text: Then Tobit answered his son Tobias, 'My child, remember to find a trustworthy man who will go with you for your journey. We will pay him his wages once you return, so go and seek him out.'
verses.comment: Tobit encourages seeking God's guidance in choosing companions, echoing Abraham's care in Genesis 24.

verses.text: Tobias went outside and found the angel Raphael standing before him, but he did not know he was an angel of God.
verses.comment: The theme of angels appearing in human form is common in Scripture (see Hebrews 13:2).

verses.text: Tobias said to him, 'Can you go with me to Rages in Media? Do you know that route?'
verses.comment: Tobias seeks guidance from one who knows the way – a reminder of the biblical wisdom of seeking counsel.

verses.text: Raphael answered, 'Yes, I know it well. I have traveled there many times and I know all the roads. I have stayed with our kinsman Gabael, who lives in Rages of Media. It’s a journey of two days from Ecbatana to Rages, for Rages is located in the mountains of Media.'
verses.comment: The angel asserts familiarity with the way, prefiguring Christ as the One who knows and is the Way (cf. John 14:6).

verses.text: Tobias said to him, 'If you will come with me, I will pay you wages. Come with me and guide me safely; I will also pay you.'
verses.comment: Tobias offers to compensate the guide—demonstrating fairness and just reward, reminiscent of passages about the worker's wage (Luke 10:7).

verses.text: Raphael replied, 'I will go with you. I am familiar with all the ways; I have even spent the night with our kinsman Gabael.'
verses.comment: Raphael emphasizes his intimacy with the family, reflecting the angel's hidden role as a divine helper.

verses.text: Then Tobias went in and informed his father Tobit, saying, 'I have found someone from the Israelites who will go with me.' He replied, 'Call the man to me, so I may learn to what tribe he belongs and whether he is trustworthy to go with you.'
verses.comment: Tobit's concern for heritage and trustworthiness reflects biblical care for faithfulness and communal bonds.

verses.text: Tobias called Raphael and he came in. Tobit greeted him first and said, 'Young man, to which family and tribe do you belong?'
verses.comment: Tobit’s questioning shows a concern for tradition and belonging—values that underpin unity in faith and practice.

verses.text: Raphael replied, 'Are you searching for a tribe or a family, or are you seeking a hired man to go with your son?' Tobit answered, 'I wish to know, my brother, both your family and your name.'
verses.comment: Names and genealogy are significant throughout Scripture (cf. Matthew 1), emphasizing continuity of God's plan.

verses.text: Then Raphael said, 'I am Azariah, son of the great Hananiah, one of your relatives.'
verses.comment: The angel uses a human name and lineage, prefiguring ways God works through mediators in salvation history.

verses.text: Tobit said, 'Welcome, my brother. Do not be angry with me for wanting to know your family and lineage. You seem to be a trustworthy and good man.'
verses.comment: Hospitality and discernment are presented as virtues.

verses.text: He added, 'I knew Hananiah and Nathan, the two sons of the great Shemeliah, who went with me to Jerusalem and worshiped with me there.'
verses.comment: Connection through shared worship highlights the unity and continuity of true worship.

verses.text: They were not led astray; your kindred are good men. You are of good lineage.'
verses.comment: The emphasis on faithful ancestry reflects on the importance of continuity and right teaching in the faith.

verses.text: Then Raphael said, 'I will go with Tobias. Do not be afraid. We will return to you safe and sound.'
verses.comment: A reassurance of God's providence through angelic guidance parallels divine care for His people.

verses.text: Tobit said to him, 'May God go with you, and may his angel accompany you on your way.'
verses.comment: Tobit’s blessing invokes the angelic protection promised elsewhere in Scripture.

verses.text: So they got ready to go; Tobias kissed his father and mother. Tobit said to Tobias, 'May you have a safe journey.'
verses.comment: Parental blessing for a son recalls the patriarchal sending of children with prayerful support.

verses.text: Anna, his mother, started weeping and said to Tobit, 'Why have you sent away our son? Isn’t he the staff of our hands as he enters and leaves before us?'
verses.comment: Maternal sorrow echoes other biblical accounts of mothers anxious for their sons (cf. Rachel for Benjamin).

verses.text: Do not be deceived; the money is nothing compared to our child. What the Lord has given us to live on is enough.'
verses.comment: Anna’s words highlight trust in God’s provision over material concerns (see Matthew 6:25–34).

verses.text: But Tobit said to her, 'Do not worry; our child will return safe. You will see him again, and your eyes will behold him.'
verses.comment: Tobit speaks hope in God’s providence and the ultimate reunion of loved ones.

verses.text: Anna replied, 'Stop deceiving me. My son is gone.' And she began to weep.
verses.comment: Anna’s fear and sorrow remind us of the cost of faith and trust in God’s promises.

verses.text: Tobit replied to her, 'Be quiet and do not worry. He is in good health, and there will be nothing wrong with him on his journey.'
verses.comment: Tobit’s steadfastness in adversity reflects the call to trust in God’s unseen protection.

verses.text: So Anna stopped crying.
verses.comment: The chapter ends with comfort—underscoring peace through faith, trust in divine providence, and intercessory help, themes deepened throughout the history of the church.
